entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued May 31 at 4:01PM AKDT until May 31 at 10:00PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 PM AKDT THIS EVENING FOR HOT DRY AND WINDY CONDITIONS FOR WEST ANCHORAGE AND THE ANCHORAGE HILLSIDE... * Winds...Southeast winds 12 to 18 mph with gusts to 25 mph. * Timing...Winds will develop in the early evening. * Relative Humidity...As low as 15 percent.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued May 31 at 1:53PM AKDT until May 31 at 10:00PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FLOOD ADVISORY FOR SNOWMELT NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 2 PM AKDT MONDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by snowmelt continues due to warmer temperatures. * WHERE...Including the following area, Copper River Basin. * WHEN...Until 200 PM AKDT Monday.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued May 31 at 9:23AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...INCREASED FIRE DANGER THIS COMING WEEK... Conditions remain dry across Southeast Alaska and temperatures will rise to the upper 70s across much of the region over the next few days. Fine fuels are dry and there is a risk of camp fires getting out of control. Winds will remain light, which is a mitigating circumstance working in our favor.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Chichagof Island; Glacier Bay; Haines Borough and Lynn Canal; Juneau Borough and Northern Admiralty Island; Taiya Inlet and Klondike Highway

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued May 31 at 8:35PM MDT until June 01 at 12:00PM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...SNOW IN THE MOUNTAINS TONIGHT ESPECIALLY WEST OF DENVER... .A wet spring storm system will bring snow to much of the northern Colorado mountains tonight into Wednesday morning. The heaviest snow is expected to be over the higher foothills and mountains from Boulder county south across Gilpin, Clear Creek and northern Jefferson counties. A band of moderate to heavy snow is expected to

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued May 31 at 4:35PM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Very Heavy Rainfall Possible Across South Florida This Weekend... The latest long range models are showing an area of low pressure developing over the Southern Gulf of Mexico moving northeast across the Florida Peninsula this weekend. This will allow for deep tropical moisture to work into South Florida from the tropics with PWAT values getting up into the 2.1 to 2.4 inch range which
entry.cap:areaDesc: Broward; Collier; Glades; Hendry; Mainland Monroe; Miami-Dade; Palm Beach

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued May 31 at 3:00PM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Runoff has begun, with significant rises on area streams... Area streams have risen the last day or two from significant precipitation that occurred last weekend. This included two to four inches of precipitation in the foothills, and one to three feet of heavy wet snowfall in the higher elevations of the mountains. The newer snow may be ripe to quickly melt off with warmer temperatures

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued May 31 at 9:55PM CDT until May 31 at 11:00PM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 PM CDT THIS EVENING FOR NORTHERN CHILDRESS COUNTY... At 955 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Up to 4 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is already occurring.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued May 31 at 8:20PM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: Light snow showers and low cloud ceilings over the I-80 Summit has resulted in low visibility the past few hours. As commuters travel in the higher terrain, they should expect to encounter patchy fog and reduced visibility from light rain and snow showers. Please reduce vehicle speeds while commuting this evening between Laramie and Cheyenne across I-80 due to low visibility at
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Laramie Range; South Laramie Range Foothills

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued May 31 at 3:00PM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Runoff has begun, with significant rises on area streams... Area streams have risen the last day or two from significant precipitation that occurred last weekend. This included two to four inches of precipitation in the foothills, and one to three feet of heavy wet snowfall in the higher elevations of the mountains. The newer snow may be ripe to quickly melt off with warmer temperatures
